subject: RE: [junit] junit and cygwin
msgSnippet: I completely avoid all of the cygwin CLASSPATH problem by using ant, having a CLASSPATH of . and then adding to it within my ant build file. Simon
messageBody:
I completely avoid all of the cygwin CLASSPATH problem by using ant, having a CLASSPATH of "." and then adding to it within my ant build file.

Simon

>-----Original Message-----
>From: Ken Gentle [mailto:j.kenneth.gentle@...]
>Sent: Wednesday, October 15, 2003 9:35 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: [junit] junit and cygwin
>
>
>At 10:15 2003-10-15, you wrote:
>>On Tue, 2003-10-14 at 16:59, Ken Gentle wrote:
>> > That's a very interesting question -- JUnit is Java,
>> > write-once-run-anywhere, remember? ;^)
>> >
>> > You don't need a special distribution. Just download
>JUnit, get your
>> > JDK/JRE visible from a cygwin shell prompt, and set it up
>just like the
>> > instructions describe.
>>
>>Not exactly. There are issues with how Cygwin deals with the
>>classpath. Cygwin does not pass along the classpath properly to your
>>Windows version JVM. You need to do something like this "java
>>-classpath `cygpath -wp $CLASSPATH` [arguments]" which changes the
>>classpath into a Windows style path. A quick google on "cygwin java
>>classpath" would have turned up "http://www.inonit.com/cygwin/faq/",
>>probably as the first hit.
>
>Sorry, I was unclear -- I've been using cygwin for years and
>tend forget to
>mention the minor path magic required. But it is really
>minor, using cygpath.
>
>
>>=jason
